clinical_study.brief_title: Intravenous Acetaminophen Use With Bariatric Surgery on Morbidly Obese Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Intravenous Acetaminophen on Postoperative Pain of Morbidly Obese Patients Undergoing Laparoscopic Bariatric Surgery: A Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Bariatric patients usually require the use of either intravenous or oral opioid medications. The use of opioids, however, is often associated with side-effects such as nausea, sedation pruritus, urinary retention and respiratory depression with often delay patient discharge. This study makes use of intravenous acetaminophen , a non-opioid analgesic preoperatively to determine if this will decrease the use of opioids post-operatively for pain management in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Study Terminated per Principal Investigator's request

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Pain Relief Score on the 5-point Pain Relief Score Between Baseline and 24 Hours
primary_outcome.description: The 5-point Pain Relief Score is self-reported and scores range from 0=none, 1=little, 2=some, 3=a lot, 4=complete. Change = (24 hour score - baseline)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Pain Intensity on the 10-point Pain Intensity Scale Between Baseline and 24 Hours
secondary_outcome.description: The 10-point Pain Intensity Scale is self-reported and scores range from 0=no pain to10=worst possible. Change = (24 hour score - baseline)

secondary_outcome.measure: Response Rate - of 3=Excellent at Hour 24 Using 4-point Global Satisfaction With Regards to Overall Pain Management Rating Scale 0=Poor to 3= Excellent.
secondary_outcome.description: The 4-point patient global satisfaction of pain management scale is self-reported and scores range from 0=poor to 3=excellent. Response rate of 3=excellent at 24 hours after baseline.

arm_group.description: Preoperative administration of 1,000 mg IV Acetaminophen will be administered after induction of general anesthesia and prior to incision and every 6 hours thereafter for 24 hours.
Preoperative IV Placebo (0.9 Sodium Chloride 100 ml) will be administered after induction of general anesthesia and prior to incision and every 6 hours thereafter for 24 hours.

intervention.description: Placebo - IV administration 0.9% 100 ml Sodium Chloride (NaCl)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Morbidly Obese and body mass index (BMI) of 35
- Between ages 20-17
- Candidates for Laparoscopic Bariatric Surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- know hypersensitivity to acetaminophen or opioids
- impairment in liver function
- renal dysfunction
- mental retardation
